background: A baking process requires the mixing of chemicals A and B, where chemical A can be hazardous, and the mix must take minimum time to be effective while adhering to safety and minimum quantity requirements.
constraints: Number of units of chemical A is non-negative
Number of units of chemical B is non-negative
For every unit of chemical B, there can be at most MaxRatioAtoB units of chemical A
At least MinUnitsA units of chemical A must be present in the mixer
The total number of units in the mixer must be at least MinTotalUnits
objective: Minimize the total effective time of chemicals A and B in the mixer
description: Both chemical A and chemical B need to be added to a mixer for making bread. One unit of chemical A takes \param{TimeA} seconds to be effective while one unit of chemical B takes \param{TimeB} seconds to be effective. Because chemical A can be dangerous, there has to be at most \param{MaxRatioAtoB} as much chemical A as chemical B in the mixer. If there has to be at least \param{MinUnitsA} units of chemical A in the mixer and at least \param{MinTotalUnits} units of total chemicals in the mixer, how many units of each should be added to minimize the total time it takes for the mixed bread to be ready?

parameters.definition: Time for one unit of chemical A to be effective
Time for one unit of chemical B to be effective
Maximum allowed ratio of chemical A to chemical B
Minimum required units of chemical A
Minimum total required units of chemicals
